description.narrative: This project aims at supporting the returning IDPs and host communities. The goal is to ensure the humanitarian needs are met, but to also contribute in the rebuilding of lives and livelihoods.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of labor market survey and livelihood opportunities assessment is identified and marketable skills and growing sectors in the area developed 1.2 Number of female and male youth who have become entrepreneurs and able to start new businesses. 1.3 Number of women in small businesses with enhanced business management skills; 1.4 Number of men and women trained in business management and entrepreneurship 1.5 Number of women Organized in MSEs groups each comprises 10 members 1.6 Number of trainees provided with startup kits (materials, equipment and instruments) as well as for vocational colleges 1.7 Number of youth and women Provisioned business startup seed money 1.8 Number of women each comprises 10 members in small businesses with enhanced business management skills are able to increase live supporting efforts 2.1 # of functional Peace committee and conferences, structured dialogues, & reconciliation forums are established in each woreda 2.2 # of functional joint community projects implemented in border areas with the involvement of ethnic Gedeo & Guji Oromos; 2.3 # of functioning peace-building structures that engage conflict-affected communities in peace and/or reconciliation processes; 2.4 # of conflict risk assessments is done that are capable to inform development planning in key sectors. 2.5 # of series of structured intra and inter-community dialogues at kebele level with all social groups and stakeholders Strengthened 2.6 Number of local authorities & experts trained on conflict sensitivity, conflict management, and dispute resolution. 3.1 # of documents developed on institutional capacity gap assessment, devised capacity development plan based on identified gaps and provided capacity building support for selected institutions. 3.2 # of people with enhanced awareness on early recovery and durable solutions programming; 3.3 At least two to three ToT trainings has not been provided to programming experts and government officials on early

comment.narrative:
OUTPUT 1: INCREASED ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES AND INCOME GENERATING CAPACITY FOR YOUTH AND WOMEN RETURNEES
1.1 No market and livelihood survey conducted in the project area 1.2 There are no youths who are trained in vocational skill development 1.3 There are no youths who are trained in business management and entrepreneurship 1.4 No youth entrepreneurs who have graduated and received startup kits 1.5 There are no women who are organized into MSEs 1.6 No women who are trained in business management and entrepreneurship 1.7 The lack of employment and livelihood opportunities, for young people, is one of the major causes of frustration and discontent, and a possible ‘push factor’ in the incitement of individuals to violence.
OUTPUT 2: SOCIAL COHESION AND PEACEFUL CO-EXISTENCE BETWEEN GEDEO AND GUJI COMMUNITIES RESTORED
2.1 Very few peace committees established and strengthened 2.2 No joint community projects implemented between Gedeo & Guji Oromos 2.3 There is no well-structured intra and inter-community dialogues at kebele level 2.4 No youth and women-led reconciliation events held 2.5 local authorities and experts are not trained on conflict sensitivity and management 2.6 Very limited authorities & experts trained on conflict sensitivity, conflict management, and dispute resolution.
OUTPUT 3: LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITIES CAPACITY TO EFFECTIVELY ENGAGE IN EARLY RECOVERY AND DURABLE SOLUTION COORDINATION, PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION AND MONITORING STRENGTHENED
3.1 No institutional capacity gap assessment has been conducted among the implementing partners 3.2 No multi-stakeholder and consultative workshops conducted and durable solution platform has been established and conduct meetings regularly 3.3 ToT trainings has not been provided to programming experts and government officials on early recovery and durable solution 3.4 No comprehensive socio-economic recovery needs assessment conducted, and multi-sectoral early recovery response framework de

At least 2 labor market survey and livelihood opportunities assessment is identified and marketable skills and growing sectors in the area developed 1.2 About 280 youths (40% female) have received vocational skill in relevant skills to the market and engaged in business to support their live supporting effort. 1.3 At least 500 trainees are Provided with startup kits (materials, equipment and instruments) as well as for vocational colleges. 1.4 At least 380 graduates trained in business management and entrepreneurship training. 1.5 At least 20O women group are organized in MSEs groups each comprises 10 members 1.6 At least 380 youth and women entrepreneurs’ groups are graduated and Provided with business startup seed money and are fully engaged with the new skill. 1.7 At least 280 youths attend vocational skill training and 200 women’s knowledge and skill in business management improved engaged in business to support their live supporting effort Provisioned business startup seed money. 1.8 About 350 women each comprises 10 members in small businesses with enhanced business management skills are able to increase live supporting efforts 2.1 At least 12 functioning peace conferences and peace dialogues are strengthened and are in engaged in peace building work to ensure peaceful coexistence among the communities 2.2 At least Four joint community-based livelihoods and economic infrastructure investment projects are supported; that would bring communities towards a shared goal and ensure peaceful coexistence and peace building mechanisms. 2.3 About 24 functioning peace‐building structures that engage conflict‐affected communities in peace and/or reconciliation processes; 2.4 # of conflict risk assessments is done that are capable to inform development planning in key sectors. 2.5 at least 35 series of structured intra and inter-community dialogues at kebele level is implemented with all social groups and stakeholders are Strengthen. 2.6 about 90 local authorities & experts are trained on conflict sensitivity, conflict management, and dispute resolution and assisted in conflict resolution and peace building 3.1 At least one study on institutional capacity gap assessment, devise capacity development plan is developed, and capacity building supported for selected institutions and provided an indicative for enhanced capacity development of the regions. 3.2 At least 3 multi-stakeholder durable solution platform established and regularly conduct meetings and provided guidance for effective implementation. 3.3 At least 75 experts attend ToT training on Early recovery and Durable Solutions Programming 3.4 At least 2 to 3 multi-stakeholder consultative meeting is organized and validated the recovery and response framework. 3.5 at least 3 a multi-sectoral early recovery response framework implemented; 3.6 One documents on comprehensive assessment on domestic financing, resource mobilization and partnership development at national level is developed with inclusion of targeted regions and has become a legal document. 3.7 At least two bi-annual and annual consultative workshops are organized to evaluate the performance and achievement of the recovery response 3.8 A minimum one comprehensive framework developed and agreed and functional

1.1. 2 labor market surveys and livelihood opportunities assessments have been identified and marketable skills and growing sectors in the area developed 1.2. 518 youths (40% female) have received vocational skills in relation to the market sectors and are engaged in business which will contribute to supporting their livelihoods. 1.3. 518 trainees have been provided with startup kits (materials, equipment and instruments) as well as for vocational colleges. 1.4. 518 graduates have been trained in business management and entrepreneurship 1.5. 35 women group have been organized in MSEs groups each comprising 10 members 1.6. 518 youth and women entrepreneurs’ groups have graduated and have been provided with business startup seed money and are fully engaged with the new skill areas. 1.7. 350 women each comprises 10 members in small businesses had enhanced business management skills contributing to increase live supporting efforts Output 2 2.1. 12 functioning peace conferences and peace dialogues have been strengthened and currently engaged in peace building work which will ensure peaceful coexistence among the communities 2.2. 10 joint community-based livelihoods and economic infrastructure investment projects have been supported which is contributing to bring communities towards a shared goal, peaceful coexistence and peace building mechanisms 2.3. 62 functioning peace‐building structures have been established and are currently engaged in peace and/or reconciliation processes 2.4. One conflict risk assessment has been conducted to inform development planning in key sectors. 2.5. 56 series of structured intra and inter-community dialogues at kebele level have been implemented which strengthened all social groups and stakeholders on the peace process 2.6. 100 local authorities & experts have been trained on conflict sensitivity, conflict management, and dispute resolution and tools provided to assist in conflict resolution and peace building Output 3 3.1. One study on institutional capacity gap assessment, devise capacity development plan has been conducted and capacity building supported for the selected institutions. 3.2. 4 multi-stakeholder durable solution platforms have been established, and regular meetings conducted to ensure effective implementation of project activities 3.3. 200 experts have attended ToT training on Early Recovery and Durable Solutions Programming 3.4. One multi-stakeholder consultative meeting has been organized and the forum used to validate a recovery and response framework 3.5. 3 multi-sectoral early recovery response frameworks have been implemented 3.6. One documents on comprehensive assessment on domestic financing, resource mobilization and partnership development at national level has been developed and endorsed as a legal document 3.7. Two bi-annual and annual consultative workshops have been organized to evaluate the performance and achievement of the recovery response 3.8. One comprehensive framework has been developed and agreed with all stakeholders and currently in use

1.1. Deliver vocational skill development, entrepreneurship and business management trainings to 100 youths (40% female) and providing support to vocational colleges. 1.2. Provide startup kits (materials, equipment and instruments) to youth (40% female) trainees as well as for vocational colleges 2.1. Provide financial and technical support to traditional conflict resolution & peacebuilding systems and activities at community level. 2.2. Support community-based livelihoods and economic infrastructure investment projects (such as roads, bridges, NRM structures) that would bring communities to work towards a shared goal 2.3. Establishing peace clubs at schools to engage youth in peace activities 2.4. Provide training to local security personnel in peace process in 4 woredas of West Guji and Gedeo Zones 3.1. Establish multi-stakeholder recovery / durable solution platform and hold regular meetings leading to the development, coordination and monitoring of the implementation of the recovery action. 3.2. Office supplies and stationaries for woreda finance, DRMO and other implementing partners 3.3. Monitoring and supervision of project activities by woreda finance office and other implementing partners 3.4. Review meetings at the end of each quarter to evaluate and accelerate project progresses 3.5. Mid-term evaluation of the project 3.5. Capacity building and south-south experience exchange for government and UNDP staff

1.1 vocational skill development, entrepreneurship, and business management trainings to 175 youths (40% female) and providing support to vocational colleges delivered. 1.2 startup kits (materials, equipment, and instruments) to 175 youth (40% female) trainees as well as for vocational colleges provided 2.1. financial and technical support to 40 traditional conflict resolution & peacebuilding systems and activities at community level provided. 2.2 . Eight [8] community-based livelihoods and economic infrastructure investment projects (such as roads, bridges, NRM structures) that would bring communities to work towards a shared goal supported 2.3. Forty [40] peace clubs at schools to engage youth in peace activities established. 2.4. training to 100 local security personnel in peace process in 4 woredas of West Guji and Gedeo Zones Provided 3.1. Four [4] multi-stakeholder recovery / durable solution platform and hold regular meetings leading to the development, coordination and monitoring of the implementation of the recovery action established. 3.2 Office supplies and stationaries for 4 woreda finance, DRMO and other implementing partners supported 3.3. Monitoring and supervision of project activities by 4 woreda finance office and other implementing partners conducted 3.4. Four [4] review meetings at the end of each quarter to evaluate and accelerate project progresses organized at regional level. 3.5. Mid-term evaluation of the project done.
